text: have you ever gotten lost in the slow
drip of a liquid motion toy on your desk
well it seems like researchers that the
University of Oxford must have at some
point or other they recently adapted a
3d printer one of those devices that
build solid objects a layer at a time to
form colorful objects from aqueous
droplets filled with dye but these
aren't just any droplets the tiny
droplets have a diameter half the size
of a human hair and they're made of
water surrounded by lipids the fatty
molecules that form the outer barrier or
membrane of a cell when the researchers
led by chemist Hagen Bailey print their
droplets onto a platform they deposit
them in an oil bath because of the
repulsion between oil and water the
droplets stay intact and the surrounding
lipids ensure that the globs stick to
one another forming a network the Oxford
scientists think that someday this
printing method could be used in tissue
engineering for instance if the droplets
were loaded with cells the globular
networks might be coaxed to grow into
new tissue or even interface with
existing tissue for wound healing but
that's not all the 3d printing method
might be good for the researchers also
used it to make a shape-shifting
structure see this flower like set of
droplet the ones on the bottom are
filled with a high concentration of
potassium chloride salt and the ones on
the top are filled with a low
concentration after they're printed over
the course of hours water from the
droplets on top flows into the droplets
on the bottom because of a process
called osmosis
when this happens for the flower-like
droplet Network the droplets on top
shrink and the droplets on the bottom
blow up causing the whole structure to
curl into a sphere this concept the
researchers say might one day be used to
trigger drug release from a delivery
device but for now they're taking things
one drop at a time this is Lauren Wolfe
reporting for chemical and engineering
news
